metadata.titleEn: WATER: Dataset of ground truth measurement synchronizing with ALOS PALSAR in the Linze grassland foci experimental area on Jun. 27, 2008
metadata.description:
The dataset of ground truth measurement synchronizing with ALOS PALSAR was obtained in the Linze grassland foci experimental area on Jun. 27, 2008.
    The data were in FBD mode and HH/HV polarization combinations, and the overpass time was approximately at 23:41 BJT. Observations were carried out in the reed plot A, the saline plot B, the alfalfa plot D and the barley plot E, which were divided into 6×6 subsites, with each one spanning a 120×120 m2 plot. Soil gravimetric moisture, volumetric moisture, and soil bulk density after drying by the cutting ring and the mean soil temperature from 0-5cm by the probe thermometer were measured in A and B; the soil temperature, soil moisture, the loss tangent, soil conductivity, the real part and the imaginary part of soil complex permittivity by the POGO soil sensor, the mean soil temperature from 0-5cm by the probe thermometer, and soil gravimetric moisture, volumetric moisture, and soil bulk density after drying by the cutting ring in D and E.
    Data were archived in Excel file. See WATER: Dataset of setting of the sampling plots and stripes in the foci experimental area of Linze station for more information.

background: Radar remote sensing has demonstrated its applicability to the retrieval of basin-scale soil moisture. The mechanism of radar backscattering from soils is complicated and strongly influenced by surface roughness. Surface soil moisture (mv) is important in agronomic, hydrological, and meteorological processes at all spatial scales. The ability of inferring mv using both active and passive microwave techniques has been intensively demonstrated. It is well known that space-borne microwave radiometers and scatterometers possess the advantage of high revisit capacity but are deficient in coarse spatial resolution. On the contrary, synthetic aperture radar (SAR) sensors have the capability to provide finer spatial resolution, on the order of tens of meters, meeting most spatial requirements for watershed management and hydrological applications. The advanced IEM (AIEM) improves the calculation accuracy of scattering coefficient by keeping the absolute phase term in Greens function which was neglected by IEM. In the IEM and AIEM, surface roughness is an essential input, thus, if only a single configuration (e.g., one polarization, one frequency) of radar data is available, roughness parameters should be known as a priori information in order to retrieve soil moisture using these models.
research objective: This study aims to simultaneously obtain surface roughness parameters (standard deviation of surface height σ and correlation length cl) along with soil moisture from multi-angular ASAR images by using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the AIEM.
challenges: The key challenge is the presence of vegetation cover, which significantly impacts the estimates of surface roughness and soil moisture. Field measuring surface roughness is very time-consuming and almost impractical at the regional scale. Moreover, appreciable inaccuracies may occur due to various deployments of instrumentation, sampling strategy, and the ambiguous scale effect during field campaigns and data post-processing.
methods: The method firstly used a semi-empirical relationship that relates the roughness slope, Zs (Zs = σ2 /cl) and the difference in backscattering coefficient (Δσ) from two ASAR images acquired with different incidence angles. Then, the deduced roughness parameters were used for the retrieval of soil moisture in association with the AIEM. An evaluation of the proposed method was performed in an experimental area in the middle stream of the Heihe River Basin, where the Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (WATER) was taken place.
dataset: The study was carried out at one of the W A TER foci experimental areas (FEAs). Linze grassland (LZG; 100 ◦04 ′ E, 39 ◦15 ′ N), which covers an area of 2 × 2 km 2 , locates in Linze county, Zhangye city in the middle stream of the Heihe River Basin. During the field campaigns conducted in the intensive observation period (IOP) from May to August 2008, five experimental sites (ESs), each 360 × 360 m 2 in size, were established. Ground truths, including soil moisture, land surface temperature (T), and bulk density, were collected at all five ESs concurrently with radar acquisitions. ASAR operates at C-band (5.3 GHz) and was launched onboard ENVISAT in 2002. In this investigation, three contiguous ASAR images in alternating polarization precision (APP) modes with different incidence angles ranging from IS1 (18.4 ◦) to IS7 (43.9 ◦) were acquired.
findings: It is demonstrated that the proposed method is feasible to achieve reliable estimation of soil water content.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) sensors in soil moisture retrieval in remote sensing?
Definition.Answer: Synthetic aperture radar (SAR) sensors are significant in soil moisture retrieval due to their ability to provide finer spatial resolution, on the order of tens of meters, which meets the spatial requirements for watershed management and hydrological applications. Unlike microwave radiometers and scatterometers, which have high revisit capacity but coarse spatial resolution, SAR sensors offer improved spatial detail necessary for accurate soil moisture estimation.

Definition.Question: What challenges do vegetation cover pose in the estimation of soil moisture and surface roughness using remote sensing techniques?
Definition.Answer: Vegetation cover poses significant challenges in the estimation of soil moisture and surface roughness using remote sensing techniques because it affects the accuracy of these estimates. It complicates the radar backscattering mechanism and can lead to inaccuracies due to variations in vegetation type, density, and moisture content. Additionally, field measurement of surface roughness under vegetation cover is time-consuming and impractical at regional scales, contributing to potential inaccuracies.

Comparison.Question: What are the similarities and differences in challenges faced when collecting soil moisture data in the Linze grassland compared to the dense observation area using different radar technologies?
Comparison.Answer: Both locations face challenges related to vegetation cover impacting soil moisture estimation. However, the Linze grassland focuses on broader experimental sites with concurrent radar acquisitions, whereas the dense observation area utilizes specific sample plots with detailed measurements. The challenges in Linze also include scale effects and field measurement impracticalities, whereas the dense observation area emphasizes precise data collection methods like drying soil samples for moisture content.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of multi-angular radar data enhance the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval in the presence of surface roughness variability?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of multi-angular radar data allows for the simultaneous retrieval of surface roughness parameters, which are crucial for accurate soil moisture estimation. This is achieved through a two-step retrieval scheme based on advanced models like AIEM, which can deduce roughness parameters from differences in backscattering coefficients at varying incidence angles.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of vegetation cover on the accuracy of soil moisture and surface roughness data collection in radar remote sensing experiments?
Interpretation.Answer: Vegetation cover poses significant challenges to the accuracy of soil moisture and surface roughness estimations, as it can obscure or alter radar backscatter signals. This necessitates careful consideration of vegetation effects and may require additional data or models to adjust for these influences during data collection and processing.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can ground truth data, such as soil moisture and bulk density, be effectively integrated with satellite radar data to improve the reliability of soil moisture models?
Interpretation.Answer: Ground truth data provides essential validation and calibration for satellite radar data, ensuring that models accurately reflect real-world conditions. By collecting concurrent ground truth data during satellite passes, researchers can refine models and parameters, such as surface roughness, to enhance the reliability of soil moisture retrievals from radar remote sensing.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in accurately retrieving soil moisture data from radar remote sensing?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The presence of vegetation cover significantly impacts the estimates of surface roughness and soil moisture. Additionally, field measuring surface roughness is time-consuming and almost impractical at a regional scale, leading to potential inaccuracies due to various instrumentation deployments, sampling strategies, and scale effects during field campaigns and data processing.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to difficulties in using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) for soil moisture estimation on a basin scale?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The mechanism of radar backscattering from soils is complicated and strongly influenced by surface roughness. If only a single configuration of radar data is available, roughness parameters should be known as a priori information to retrieve soil moisture. Vegetation cover also adds complexity, impacting surface roughness and moisture estimates.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the consequences of vegetation cover on the estimation of surface roughness and soil moisture using radar remote sensing?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Vegetation cover significantly impacts the estimates of surface roughness and soil moisture, posing a challenge to obtaining accurate measurements because it complicates the retrieval process and can introduce inaccuracies due to varying field conditions and measurement strategies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of conducting ground-based synchronous observations alongside ALOS PALSAR satellite data in the Linze grassland area?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The main goal of performing ground-based synchronous observations with ALOS PALSAR data is to develop and validate algorithms for retrieving soil moisture and soil salinity using active microwave remote sensing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are utilized to account for the impact of vegetation cover on the estimation of soil moisture and surface roughness in radar remote sensing data collection?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methods involve using a semi-empirical relationship that relates roughness slope and the difference in backscattering coefficients from ASAR images with different incidence angles, which helps in deducing roughness parameters and retrieving soil moisture using AIEM.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to extract relevant soil moisture and roughness information from multi-angular ASAR images for hydrological applications?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedure involves a two-step retrieval scheme based on AIEM, where initially, roughness parameters are deduced using a semi-empirical relationship between roughness slope and backscattering coefficient differences, followed by soil moisture retrieval.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies enable the accurate retrieval of soil moisture and surface roughness parameters using remote sensing techniques in areas with significant vegetation cover?
Enablement.Answer: The methodologies include using a two-step retrieval scheme based on the Advanced Integral Equation Model (AIEM), which involves a semi-empirical relationship that relates roughness slope and the difference in backscattering coefficient from multi-angular ASAR images acquired at different incidence angles.

Enablement.Question: How can the integration of different radar data configurations improve the accuracy of soil moisture retrieval in remote sensing?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of radar data configurations, such as multi-angular ASAR images with varying incidence angles, allows for the simultaneous retrieval of surface roughness parameters and soil moisture, which improves the overall accuracy of the retrieval process.

Enablement.Question: What are the enabling conditions for conducting effective field campaigns that provide ground truth data for validating remote sensing soil moisture models?
Enablement.Answer: Effective field campaigns require concurrent collection of ground truth data, such as soil moisture, land surface temperature, and bulk density, at various experimental sites during intensive observation periods. These campaigns should be aligned with radar acquisitions to ensure reliable validation of remote sensing models.

Expectation.Question: Why might the integration of active and passive microwave techniques be expected to improve the retrieval of soil moisture at varying spatial scales?
Expectation.Answer: The integration of active and passive microwave techniques is anticipated to improve soil moisture retrieval because active techniques like synthetic aperture radar (SAR) can provide finer spatial resolution, while passive techniques like microwave radiometers have high revisit capacity. This combination could potentially overcome the limitations of coarse spatial resolution found in passive methods alone.

Expectation.Question: Why are field campaigns for measuring surface roughness considered time-consuming and impractical at a regional scale, and how might this affect data collection efforts?
Expectation.Answer: Field campaigns for measuring surface roughness are considered time-consuming and impractical at a regional scale due to the extensive manual effort required for accurate measurements and the challenges in deploying instruments and sampling strategies over large areas. This can lead to inaccuracies and inconsistencies in data collection efforts, affecting the reliability of soil moisture retrieval models.

Expectation.Question: Why might the presence of vegetation cover pose a challenge in estimating surface roughness and soil moisture, and what could be the anticipated impact on data collection methodologies?
Expectation.Answer: Vegetation cover poses a challenge in estimating surface roughness and soil moisture because it can significantly alter radar backscatter signals, complicating the retrieval process. This necessitates the development of more sophisticated data collection methodologies that can account for or mitigate the effects of vegetation, potentially increasing the complexity and cost of data acquisition.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how could the integration of multi-angular radar images improve the accuracy of soil moisture and surface roughness retrievals?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multi-angular radar images can enhance accuracy by allowing the simultaneous retrieval of surface roughness parameters and soil moisture through a two-step retrieval scheme. This method utilizes a semi-empirical relationship to deduce roughness parameters, which aids in retrieving soil moisture using advanced models like AIEM.

Assertion.Question: I don’t understand how surface roughness parameters can be accurately measured in the presence of vegetation cover.
Assertion.Answer: The method uses a semi-empirical relationship that relates the roughness slope with the difference in backscattering coefficients from two ASAR images with different incidence angles. This approach helps deduce roughness parameters despite the challenge posed by vegetation cover.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about how multi-angular data from radar images can enhance soil moisture retrieval.
Assertion.Answer: Multi-angular data allows for the simultaneous retrieval of surface roughness parameters and soil moisture. By using images with different incidence angles, the method can deduce roughness parameters which are then used to retrieve soil moisture in conjunction with the AIEM model.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of why field measuring of surface roughness is considered impractical at the regional scale.
Assertion.Answer: Field measuring of surface roughness is time-consuming and can be inaccurate due to various factors like instrumentation deployment, sampling strategy, and scale effect. These challenges make it almost impractical to conduct such measurements at a regional scale efficiently.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges of field measuring surface roughness parameters in the context of soil moisture retrieval using radar remote sensing.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the presence of vegetation cover, which significantly impacts estimates, the time-consuming nature of field measurements, and the impracticality at a regional scale. Inaccuracies may arise due to various deployments of instrumentation, sampling strategies, and the scale effect during field campaigns and data post-processing.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the potential methods for obtaining surface roughness parameters and soil moisture from multi-angular radar images.
Request/Directive.Answer: One potential method involves a two-step retrieval scheme based on the Advanced Integral Equation Model (AIEM), which uses a semi-empirical relationship to relate roughness slope and backscattering coefficient differences from radar images with different incidence angles. The deduced roughness parameters can then be used to retrieve soil moisture.

Request/Directive.Question: Please evaluate the feasibility of using synthetic aperture radar (SAR) sensors for soil moisture estimation, considering their spatial resolution and revisit capacity.
Request/Directive.Answer: SAR sensors provide finer spatial resolution on the order of tens of meters, which meets spatial requirements for watershed management and hydrological applications. They offer high revisit capacity, which is advantageous for monitoring soil moisture. This feasibility is demonstrated by the use of SAR images in the Heihe River Basin study, showing reliable soil water content estimation.
